033    /** Used to prevent massive debug dumps. See {@link #getDisplayString(String, String)} */
034    private static final int MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS = 300;
035
036        /** Left-justification constant for use in the {@link #pad(String, int, int)} method */
037        public static final int JUSTIFICATION_LEFT = 0;
038        
039        /** Center-justification constant for use in the {@link #pad(String, int, int)} method */
040        public static final int JUSTIFICATION_CENTER = 1;
041
042        /** Right-justification constant for use in the {@link #pad(String, int, int)} method */
043        public static final int JUSTIFICATION_RIGHT = 2;

045        public static Pattern scriptPattern = Pattern.compile("<(/script)", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE);

047    /** Returns true if the supplied string is null or the empty string, false otherwise
048     *
049     * @param text The string to test
050     * @return true if the supplied string is null or the empty string, false otherwise
051     */
052    public static boolean isBlank(String text) {
053        return (text == null || text.equals(""));
054    }
055
056    /** Returns true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
057     *
058     * @param text The string to test
059     * @return true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
060     */
061    public static boolean isNumeric(String text) {
062        if (text == null) {
063            return false;
064        }
065        char ch;
066        for (int i = 0; i < text.length(); i++) {
067            ch = text.charAt(i);
068            if (ch < '0' || ch > '9') {
069                return false;
070            }
071        }
072        return true;
073    }
074
075    /** Returns true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
076    * or a single decimal point. The value can have a leading negative ('-') symbol.
077    * 
078    * @param text The string to test
079    * @return true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters,
080    *   which may contain a '.' character in there somewhere.
081    */
082   public static boolean isNumericDecimal(String text) {
083       if (text == null) {
084           return false;
085       }
086       boolean seenPoint = false; // existential quandary there for you
087       char ch;
088       int len = text.length();
089       for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
090           ch = text.charAt(i);
091           if (ch=='.') {
092                   if (seenPoint) { return false; }
093                   seenPoint = true;
094           } else if (ch == '-' && i == 0) {
095                   // leading negative symbol OK
096                   if (len == 1) {
097                           // but not if it's the only character in the string
098                           return false;
099                   }
100           } else if (ch < '0' || ch > '9') {
101               return false;
102           }
103       }
104       return true;
105   }
106
107     /** Returns true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters
108     * or a single decimal point. The value can have a leading negative ('-') symbol.
109     * 
110     * This version allows exponents ("E+nn" or "E-nn") to the end of the value.
111     * 
112     * @param text The string to test
113     * @return true if the supplied string is non-null and only contains numeric characters,
114     *  which may contain a '.' character in there somewhere.
115     */
116    public static boolean isNumericDecimalExp(String text) {
117        if (text == null) {
118          return false;
119        }
120            boolean seenPoint = false; // existential quandary there for you
121            int expPos = -1;           // position of the 'E' character
122            char ch;
123            for (int i = 0; i < text.length(); i++) {
124                ch = text.charAt(i);
125                if (ch=='E') {
126                        if (expPos != -1) { return false; }
127                        expPos = i;
128                } else if (ch=='.' && expPos == -1) {
129                if (seenPoint) { return false; }
130                seenPoint = true;
131                } else if ((ch == '+' || ch == '-') && i == expPos + 1) {
132                        // + or - directly after 'E' OK
133            } else if (ch == '-' && i == 0) {
134                // leading negative symbol OK
135            } else if (ch < '0' || ch > '9') {
136                return false;
137            }
138            }
139            return true;
140    }
141
142
143    /** Ensures that a string returned from a browser (on any platform) conforms
144     * to unix line-EOF conventions. Any instances of consecutive CRs (<code>0xD</code>) 
145     * and LFs (<code>0xA</code>) in a string will be reduced to a series of CRs (the number of CRs will be the
146     * maximum number of CRs or LFs found in a row).  
147     * 
148     * @param input the input string
149     * 
150     * @return the canonicalised string, as described above
151     */
152    public static String reduceNewlines(String input) {
153        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
154        int len = input.length();
155        int crCount = 0;
156                int lfCount = 0;
157                boolean insertNewline = false;
158                char ch;
159        for (int i=0; i<len; i++) {
160                ch = input.charAt(i);
161                if (ch == (char) 0xA) {
162                        lfCount ++; insertNewline = true;
163                } else if (ch == (char) 0xD) {
164                        crCount ++; insertNewline = true;
165                } else if (insertNewline) {
166                                for (int j=0; j<Math.max(lfCount, crCount); j++) {
167                                        sb.append((char) 0xA);
168                                }
169                                insertNewline = false; lfCount=0; crCount=0;
170                                sb.append(ch);
171                } else {
172                        sb.append(ch);
173                }
174        }
175        if (insertNewline) {
176                        for (int j=0; j<Math.max(lfCount, crCount); j++) {
177                                sb.append((char) 0xA);
178                        }
179        }
180        
181        return sb.toString();
182    }
183
184
185    /**
186     * Returns the HTML-escaped form of a string. The <code>&amp;</code>,
187     * <code>&lt;</code>, <code>&gt;</code>, and <code>"</code> characters are converted to
188     * <code>&amp;amp;</code>, <code>&amp;lt;</code>, <code>&amp;gt;</code>, and
189     * <code>&amp;quot;</code> respectively.
190     * 
191     * <p>Characters in the unicode control code blocks ( apart from \t, \n and \r ) are converted to &amp;xfffd;
192     * <p>Characters outside of the ASCII printable range are converted into &amp;xnnnn; form
193     *
194     * @param string the string to convert
195     *
196     * @return the HTML-escaped form of the string
197     */
198    static public String escapeHtml(String string) {
199        if (string == null) {
200            return "";
201        }
202        char c;
203        String hex;
204        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
205        for (int i = 0; i < string.length(); i++) {
206            c = string.charAt(i);
207            // check for illegal characters
208            switch (c) {
209                case '&':
210                    sb.append("&amp;");
211                    break;
212                case '<':
213                    sb.append("&lt;");
214                    break;
215                case '>':
216                    sb.append("&gt;");
217                    break;
218                case '\"':
219                    // interestingly, &quote; (with the e) works fine for HTML display,
220                    // but not inside hidden field values
221                    sb.append("&quot;");
222                    break;
223                default:
224                        // 'illegal characters' according to ESAPI. 7f to 9f are control characters in unicode 
225                        if ( ( c <= 0x1f && c != '\t' && c != '\n' && c != '\r' ) || ( c >= 0x7f && c <= 0x9f ) ) {
226                                sb.append("&#xfffd;"); // REPLACEMENT_HEX in ESAPI's HtmlEntityCodec
227                        } else if ( c > 0x1f && c <= 0x7f ) {
228                                // safe printable
229                                sb.append(c);
230                        } else {
231                                // ESAPI didn't have the else block above, which was causing it escape everything 
232                                hex = getHexForNonAlphanumeric(c);
233                                sb.append("&#x" + hex + ";");
234                        }
235                        
236            }
237        }
238
239        return sb.toString();
240    }
241
242    /**
243     * Returns the unescaped version of a string. 
244     * Converts &amp;amp; &amp;lt; and &amp;gt; entities to their
245     * characters
246     * 
247     * @TODO all those other ones
248     *
249     * @param string The string to be unescaped.
250     * @return The unescaped version of the string.
251     */
252    private String unescapeHtml(String string)
253    {
254        string = string.replaceAll("&amp;", "&");
255        string = string.replaceAll("&lt;", "<");
256        string = string.replaceAll("&gt;", ">");
257        return string;
258    }    
259    
260    /**
261     * Returns a regex-escaped form of a string. That is, the pattern 
262     * returned by this method, if compiled into a regex, will match
263     * the supplied string exactly. 
264     *
265     * @param string the string to convert
266     *
267     * @return the HTML-escaped form of the string
268     */
269    static public String escapeRegex(String string) {
270        if (string == null) {
271            return "";
272        }
273
274        char c;
275        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
276
277        for (int i = 0; i < string.length(); i++) {
278            c = string.charAt(i);
279
280            switch (c) {
281                case '.':
282                case '+': // intentional fall-through
283                case '?': // intentional fall-through
284                case '\\': // intentional fall-through
285                case '{': // intentional fall-through
286                case '}': // intentional fall-through
287                case '[': // intentional fall-through
288                case ']': // intentional fall-through
289                case '^': // intentional fall-through
290                case '$': // intentional fall-through
291                case '(': // intentional fall-through
292                case '|': // intentional fall-through
293                case ')': // intentional fall-through
294                        sb.append("\\");
295                    sb.append(c);
296                    break;
297                default:
298                    sb.append(c);
299            }
300        }
301
302        return sb.toString();
303    }
304    
305    
306    /**
307     * Returns the csv-escaped form of a string. A csv-escaped string is
308     * used when writing to a CSV (comma-separated-value) file. It ensures
309     * that commas included within a string are quoted. We use the Microsoft-Excel
310     * quoting rules, so that our CSV files can be imported into that. These rules
311     * (derived from experimentation) are:
312     *
313     * <ul>
314     * <li>Strings without commas (,) inverted commas ("), or newlines (\n) are returned as-is.
315     * <li>Otherwise, the string is surrounded by inverted commas, and any
316     *   inverted commas within the string are doubled-up (i.e. '"' becomes '""').
317     * <li>A value that starts with any of "=", "@", "+" or "-" has a leading single apostrophe added
318     *   to prevent the value being evaluated in Excel. The leading quote is visible to the user when the
319     *   csv is opened, which may mean that it will have to be removed when roundtripping data.
320     *   This may complicate things if the user actually wants a leading single quote in their CSV value.   
321     * </ul>
322     *
323     * <p>Embedded newlines are inserted as-is, as per Excel. This will require
324     * some care whilst parsing if we want to be able to read these files.
325     *
326     * @param string the string to convert
327     *
328     * @return the csv-escaped form of the string
329     */
330    static public String escapeCsv(String string) {
331        if (string == null) {
332            return "";
333        }
334
335        boolean quoted = false;
336        // from https://www.contextis.com/en/blog/comma-separated-vulnerabilities
337        // prefix cells that start with ‘=’ , '@', '+' or '-' with an apostrophe 
338        // This will ensure that the cell isn’t interpreted as a formula, and as a bonus in Microsoft Excel the apostrophe itself will not be displayed.
339        if (string.startsWith("=") || 
340          string.startsWith("@")) {
341            // prefix the string with an a single quote char to escape it
342            string = "'" + string;
343            quoted = true; // not sure need to quote here, but doesn't hurt
344        } else if ((string.startsWith("+") || string.startsWith("-")) && 
345                (string.length() == 1 || !Text.isNumericDecimalExp(string))) {
346                // numbers can legitimately start with '+' or '-' but anything else should be escaped
347                string = "'" + string;
348            quoted = true; 
349        }
350
351        
352        if (string.indexOf(',') == -1 && string.indexOf('"') == -1 && string.indexOf('\n') == -1 && !quoted) {
353                return string;
354        }
355        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\"\"");
356        string = "\"" + string + "\"";
357
358        return string;
359    }
360
361    /** Given a csv-encoded string (as produced by the rules in {@link #escapeCsv(String)},
362     *  produces a List of Strings which represent the individual values in the string.
363     *  Note that this method is *not* equivalent to calling <code>Arrays.asList(astring.split(","))</code>.
364     *
365     * <p>Setting the whitespaceSensitive parameter to false allows leading and trailing
366     * whitespace in *non-quoted* values to be removed, e.g. if the input string <code>text</code> is:
367     *
368     * <pre class="code">
369     * abc,def,  ghi, j k ,"lmn"," op "," q,r","""hello""", "another"
370     * </pre>
371     *
372     * then <code>parseCsv(text, <b>false</b>)</code> will return the strings:
373     * <pre class="code">
374     * abc
375     * def
376     * ghi
377     * j k
378     * lmn
379     *  op        <i>(this String has one leading space, and a trailing space after 'p')</i>
380     *  q,r       <i>(this String has one leading space)</i>
381     * "hello"
382     * another
383     * </pre>
384     *
385     * and <code>parseCsv(text, <b>true</b>)</code> would throw a ParseException (since the
386     * final element is a quoted value, but begins with a space).
387     *
388     * If the <code>, "another"</code> text is removed, however, then
389     * <code>parseCsv(text, true)</code> would return the following:
390     *
391     * and <code>parseCsv(text, true)</code> will return the string
392     * <pre>
393     * abc
394     * def
395     *   ghi      <i>(this String has two leading spaces)</i>
396     *  j k       <i>(this String has one leading space and a trailing space after the 'k' character)</i>
397     * lmn
398     *  op        <i>(this String has one leading space, and a trailing space after 'p')</i>
399     *  q,r       <i>(this String has one leading space)</i>
400     * "hello"
401     * </pre>
402     *
403     * <p>Most applications would want to use the 'whiteSpaceSensitive=false' form of this function, since
404     * (a) less chance of a ParseException, and (b) it's what an end-user would normally
405     * expect. This can be performed by calling the {@link #parseCsv(String)} method.
406     *
407     * <p>Whitespace is determined by using the <code>Character.isSpaceChar()</code> method,
408     * which is Unicode-aware.
409     *
410     * @param text   The CSV-encoded string to parse
411     * @param whitespaceSensitive   If set to true, will trim leading and trailing whitespace in *non-quoted* values.
412     *
413     * @return a List of Strings. The returned List is guaranteed to always contain at least one element.
414     *
415     * @throws NullPointerException if the text passed to this method is null
416     * @throws ParseException if a quoted value contains leading whitespace before the
417     *  opening quote, or after the trailing quote.
418     * @throws ParseException if a quoted value has a start quote, but no end quote, or
419     *   if a value has additional text after a quoted value (before the next comma or EOL).
420     */
421    static public List<String> parseCsv(String text, boolean whitespaceSensitive)
422        throws ParseException {
423        if (text == null) {
424            throw new NullPointerException("null text");
425        }
426
427        // parse state: 
428        //   0=searching for new value (at start of line or after comma) 
429        //   1=consuming non-quoted values
430        //   2=consuming quoted value
431        //   3=consumed first quote within a quoted value (may be termining quote or a "" sequence)
432        //   4=consuming whitespace up to next comma/EOL (after quoted value, not whitespaceSensitive)
433        int parseState = 0;
434        int length = text.length();
435        String element;
436        List<String> result = new ArrayList<String>();
437        char ch;
438        StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder();
439
440        for (int pos = 0; pos < length; pos++) {
441            ch = text.charAt(pos);
442
443            // System.out.println("pos " + pos + ", state=" + parseState + ", nextchar=" + ch + ", buf=" + buffer);
444            switch (parseState) {
445                case 0:
446                    if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
447                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
448                            buffer.append(ch);
449                            parseState = 1;
450                        } else {
451                            // ignore
452                        }
453                    } else if (ch == '"') {
454                        parseState = 2;
455                    } else if (ch == ',') {
456                        result.add(""); // add an empty element; state remains unchanged
457                    } else {
458                        buffer.append(ch);
459                        parseState = 1;
460                    }
461                    break;
462                case 1:
463                    if (ch == ',') {
464                        element = buffer.toString();
465                        if (!whitespaceSensitive) {
466                            element = element.trim();
467                        }
468                        result.add(element);
469                        buffer.setLength(0);
470                        parseState = 0;
471                    } else {
472                        buffer.append(ch);
473                    }
474                    break;
475                case 2:
476                    if (ch == '"') {
477                        parseState = 3;
478                    } else {
479                        buffer.append(ch);
480                    }
481                    break;
482                case 3:
483                    if (ch == '"') {
484                        buffer.append('"');
485                        parseState = 2;
486                    } else if (ch == ',') {
487                        result.add(buffer.toString());
488                        buffer.setLength(0);
489                        parseState = 0;
490                    } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
491                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
492                            throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing whitespace after close quote character", pos);
493                        }
494                        parseState = 4;
495                    } else {
496                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
497                    }
498                    break;
499                case 4:
500                    if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
501                        // consume and ignore
502                    } else if (ch == ',') {
503                        result.add(buffer.toString());
504                        buffer.setLength(0);
505                        parseState = 0;
506                    } else {
507                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
508                    }
509                    break;
510                    
511                default:
512                    throw new IllegalStateException("Illegal state '" + parseState + "' in parseCsv");
513            }
514        }
515
516        // if state is 2, we are in the middle of a quoted value
517        if (parseState == 2) {
518            throw new ParseException("Missing endquote in csv text", length);
519        }
520
521        // otherwise we still need to add what's left in the buffer into the result list
522        element = buffer.toString();
523        if (parseState == 1 && !whitespaceSensitive) {
524            element = element.trim();
525        }
526        result.add(element);
527        return result;
528    }
529    
530    @FunctionalInterface
531    public interface CsvLineReader { // doesn't extend Supplier<T> as it throws exceptions
532        /** Returns the next logical line in the CSV ( quoted values can contain newlines )  
533         * 
534         * @return
535         * @throws ParseException
536         * @throws IOException
537         */
538        List<String> readLine() throws ParseException, IOException;
539    }
540    
541    // same as parseCsv(String, whitespaceSensitive) but can handle newlines in quotes by supplying a Reader
542    // the returned object will return a List<String> or null if EOF is reached
543    // ParseExceptions are wrapped in something, probably
544    static public CsvLineReader parseCsv(Reader r, boolean whitespaceSensitive) {
545        if (r == null) {
546            throw new NullPointerException("null reader");
547        }
548        return new CsvLineReader() {
549                // eof if we actually read eof or encouner a parse exception ( cannot recover )
550                boolean isAtStart = true; // for backwards compatibility with Text.parseCsv(""), first readLine() is never null
551                boolean isEOF = false;
552                        @Override
553                        public List<String> readLine() throws ParseException, IOException {
554                                if (isEOF) { return null; }
555                                
556                                // parse state: 
557                        //   0=searching for new value (at start of line or after comma) 
558                        //   1=consuming non-quoted values
559                        //   2=consuming quoted value
560                        //   3=consumed first quote within a quoted value (may be termining quote or a "" sequence)
561                        //   4=consuming whitespace up to next comma/EOL (after quoted value, not whitespaceSensitive)
562                        int parseState = 0;
563                        // int length = text.length();
564                        String element;
565                        List<String> result = new ArrayList<String>();
566                        char ch;
567                        StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder();
568                        int intChar = r.read();
569                        int pos = 1;
570                        if (intChar == -1 && !isAtStart) {
571                                isEOF = true;
572                                return null;
573                        }
574
575                        // @TODO better CRLF handling
576                        isAtStart = false;
577                        while (intChar != -1) {
578                            ch = (char) intChar;
579
580                            // System.out.println("pos " + pos + ", state=" + parseState + ", nextchar=" + ch + ", buf=" + buffer);
581                            switch (parseState) {
582                                case 0:
583                                        if (ch == '\n') {
584                                                // return result so far
585                                                element = buffer.toString();
586                                                result.add(buffer.toString());
587                                                return result;
588                                        } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
589                                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
590                                            buffer.append(ch);
591                                            parseState = 1;
592                                        } else {
593                                            // ignore
594                                        }
595                                    } else if (ch == '"') {
596                                        parseState = 2;
597                                    } else if (ch == ',') {
598                                        result.add(""); // add an empty element; state remains unchanged
599                                    } else {
600                                        buffer.append(ch);
601                                        parseState = 1;
602                                    }
603                                    break;
604                                case 1:
605                                        if (ch == '\n') {
606                                                // return result so far
607                                                element = buffer.toString();
608                                                if (!whitespaceSensitive) {
609                                                    element = element.trim();
610                                                }
611                                                result.add(buffer.toString());
612                                                return result;
613                                        } else if (ch == ',') {
614                                        element = buffer.toString();
615                                        if (!whitespaceSensitive) {
616                                            element = element.trim();
617                                        }
618                                        result.add(element);
619                                        buffer.setLength(0);
620                                        parseState = 0;
621                                    } else {
622                                        buffer.append(ch);
623                                    }
624                                    break;
625                                case 2:
626                                    if (ch == '"') {
627                                        parseState = 3;
628                                    } else {
629                                        buffer.append(ch);
630                                    }
631                                    break;
632                                case 3:
633                                        if (ch == '\n') {
634                                        result.add(buffer.toString());
635                                        buffer.setLength(0);
636                                        parseState = 0;
637                                        return result;
638                                        } else if (ch == '"') {
639                                        buffer.append('"');
640                                        parseState = 2;
641                                    } else if (ch == ',') {
642                                        result.add(buffer.toString());
643                                        buffer.setLength(0);
644                                        parseState = 0;
645                                    } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
646                                        if (whitespaceSensitive) {
647                                                isEOF = true;
648                                            throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing whitespace after close quote character", pos);
649                                        }
650                                        parseState = 4;
651                                    } else {
652                                        isEOF = true;
653                                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
654                                    }
655                                    break;
656                                case 4:
657                                        if (ch == '\n') {
658                                                // return result so far
659                                                result.add(buffer.toString());
660                                                return result;
661                                        } else if (Character.isSpaceChar(ch)) {
662                                        // consume and ignore
663                                    } else if (ch == ',') {
664                                        result.add(buffer.toString());
665                                        buffer.setLength(0);
666                                        parseState = 0;
667                                    } else {
668                                        isEOF = true;
669                                        throw new ParseException("Cannot have trailing data after close quote character", pos);
670                                    }
671                                    break;
672                                    
673                                default:
674                                    throw new IllegalStateException("Illegal state '" + parseState + "' in parseCsv");
675                            }
676                            
677                                intChar = r.read();
678                                pos++;
679                        }
680                        isEOF = true;
681
682                        // if state is 2, we are in the middle of a quoted value
683                        if (parseState == 2) {
684                            throw new ParseException("Missing endquote in csv text", pos);
685                        }
686
687                        // otherwise we still need to add what's left in the buffer into the result list
688                        element = buffer.toString();
689                        if (parseState == 1 && !whitespaceSensitive) {
690                            element = element.trim();
691                        }
692                        result.add(element);
693                        return result;
694                        }
695        };
696    }
697
698    /**
699     * Equivalent to <code>parseCsv(text, false);</code> (i.e. whitespace-insensitive parsing).
700     * Refer to the documentation for that method for more details.
701     *
702     * @see #parseCsv(String, boolean)
703     *
704     * @param text he CSV-encoded string to parse
705     * 
706     * @return a List of Strings. The returned List is guaranteed to always contain at least one element.
707     *
708     * @throws NullPointerException if the text passed to this method is null.
709     * @throws ParseException see {@link #parseCsv(String, boolean)} for details.
710     */
711    static public List<String> parseCsv(String text)
712        throws ParseException {
713        return Text.parseCsv(text, false);
714    }
715
716    /** Returns a java-escaped string. Replaces '"' with '\"'.
717     *
718     * <p>Since this is predominantly used in the query builder, I am not worrying about
719     * unicode sequences (SWIFT is ASCII) or newlines (although this may be necessary later)
720     * for multiline textboxes
721     *
722     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
723     */
724    public static String escapeJava(String string) {
725        return Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\\\"");
726    }
727
728    /** Returns a javascript string. The characters <code>'</code>,
729     * <code>"</code> and <code>\</code> are converted into their Unicode equivalents,
730     *
731     * <p>Non-printable characters are converted into unicode equivalents
732     **
733     * <p>Newlines are now replaced with "\n" 
734     *
735     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
736     */
737    public static String escapeJavascript(String string) {
738        // backslashes are always escaped
739        //string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\", "\\u005C");
740        //string = Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\\u0022");
741        //string = Text.replaceString(string, "'", "\\u0027");
742                //string = Text.replaceString(string, "\n", "\\n");
743        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
744                for (int i = 0; i<string.length(); i++) {
745                        char ch = string.charAt(i);
746                        if (ch=='\n') {
747                           sb.append("\\n");    
748                        } else if (ch=='\\' || ch=='"' || ch=='\'' || ch<32 || ch>126) {
749                                String hex = Integer.toString(ch, 16);
750                                sb.append("\\u" + "0000".substring(0, 4-hex.length()) + hex);
751                        } else {
752                                sb.append(ch);
753                        }
754                }
755                return scriptPattern.matcher(sb.toString()).replaceAll("\\\\u003C$1");
756        // return sb.toString();
757    }
758
759
760    /** Returns a javascript string. The characters <code>'</code>,
761     * <code>"</code> and <code>\</code> are converted into their Unicode equivalents,
762     *
763     * <p>Non-printable characters are converted into unicode equivalents
764     *
765     * @deprecated use {@link #escapeJavascript(String)} instead
766     * 
767     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
768     */
769    public static String escapeJavascript2(String string) {
770        // this method only exists for backwards-compatability
771        string = reduceNewlines(string);  // canonicalise CRLFs
772        return escapeJavascript(string);
773    }
774
775    
776    /** Unescapes a java-escaped string. Replaces '\"' with '"',
777     * '\\u0022' with '"', '\\u0027' with ''', '\\u005C' with '\'.
778     *
779     * <p>Since this is predominantly used in the query builder, I am not worrying about
780     * unicode sequences (SWIFT is ASCII) or newlines (although this may be necessary later)
781     * for multiline textboxes
782     *
783     * @return The java-escaped version of the string
784     */
785    public static String unescapeJava(String string) {
786        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\\"", "\"");
787        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\u0022", "\"");
788        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\u0027", "'");
789        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\u005C", "\\");
790        return string;
791    }
792
793    /** Returns a python string, escaped so that it can be enclosed in a single-quoted string. 
794     * 
795     * <p>The characters <code>'</code>,
796     * <code>"</code> and <code>\</code> are converted into their Unicode equivalents,
797     *
798     * <p>Non-printable characters are converted into unicode equivalents
799     *
800     * @return The python-escaped version of the string
801     */
802    public static String escapePython(String string) {
803        // pretty much the same as Text.escapeJavascript2(), without the reduceNewLines, which probably shouldn't be there anyway
804        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\", "\\u005C");
805        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\"", "\\u0022");
806        string = Text.replaceString(string, "'", "\\u0027");
807                string = Text.replaceString(string, "\n", "\\n");
808                StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(string.length());
809                for (int i = 0; i<string.length(); i++) {
810                        char ch = string.charAt(i);
811                        if (ch>=32 && ch<=126) {
812                                sb.append(ch);
813                        } else {
814                                String hex = Integer.toString(ch, 16);
815                                sb.append("\\u" + "0000".substring(0, 4-hex.length()) + hex);
816                        }
817                }
818        return sb.toString();
819        // return string;
820    }
821    
822    /** Escape a filename or path component. 
823     * Characters that typically have special meanings in paths (":", "/", "\") are escaped with a preceding "\" character.
824     * 
825     * Does not escape glob characters ( "*" or "?" ). 
826     * Do not use this method to escape a full file path; when escaping a file path, escape each path component separately and then join 
827     * the components with "/" characters ( see {@link #createEscapedPath(String[])} ). 
828     * 
829     * @param string the filename or path component to escape
830     * 
831     * @return the escaped form of the filename (or path component)
832     */
833    // Does not escape DOS special filenames ( "NUL", "CON", "LPT1" etc ). Remember those ? Of course you do.
834    public static String escapePathComponent(String string) {
835        string = Text.replaceString(string, "\\", "\\\\");
836        string = Text.replaceString(string, "/", "\\/");
837        string = Text.replaceString(string, ":", "\\:");
838        return string;
839    }
840    
841    /** Unescape a filename or path component. 
842     * The escape sequences "\\" , "\:" and "\/" are converted to "\", ":" and "/" respectively.
843     * All other escape sequences will raise an IllegalArgumentException 
844     *  
845     * <p>See {@link #splitEscapedPath(String)} to split an escaped path into components. 
846     *  
847     * @param pathComponent the filename or path component to unescape
848     * 
849     * @return the unescaped form of the filename or path component
850     * 
851     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if an unexpected escape is encountered, or the escape is unclosed
852     */
853    public static String unescapePathComponent(String pathComponent) {
854        if (pathComponent == null) {
855            return null;
856        }
857        char c;
858        boolean inEscape = false;
859        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(pathComponent.length());
860        for (int i = 0; i < pathComponent.length(); i++) {
861            c = pathComponent.charAt(i);
862            if (inEscape) {
863                switch (c) {
864                        case '\\': 
865                    case '/': // intentional fall-through
866                    case ':': // intentional fall-through
867                        sb.append(c);
868                        break;
869                    default:
870                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unexpected escape '\\" + c + "' in filename");
871                }
872                inEscape = false;
873            } else {
874                switch (c) {
875                        case '\\': 
876                                inEscape = true;
877                                break;
878                        default:
879                                sb.append(c);
880                }
881            }
882        }
883        if (inEscape) {
884                throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unclosed escape in filename");
885        }
886        return sb.toString();
887    }
888
889    // need to escape the \ in a regex ( \\ ) in a String ( \\\\ )
890    private static Pattern splitPathPattern = Pattern.compile("(?<!\\\\)/"); 
891    
892        /** Split a path, but allow forward slashes in path components if they're escaped by a preceding '\' character.
893     * Individual path components returned by this method will be unescaped.
894     *
895     * <pre>
896     * splitPath(null) = NPE
897     * splitPath("") = [ "" ]
898     * splitPath("abc") = [ "abc" ]
899     * splitPath("abc/def/ghi") = [ "abc", "def", "ghi" ]
900     * splitPath("abc\\/def/ghi") = [ "abc/def", "ghi" ]
901     * </pre>
902     * 
903     * <p>Opposite of {@link #createEscapedPath(String[])}
904     */
905    public static String[] splitEscapedPath(String escapedPath) {
906        String[] result = splitPathPattern.split(escapedPath);
907        for (int i=0; i<result.length; i++) {
908                result[i] = Text.unescapePathComponent(result[i]);
909        }
910        return result;
911    }
912    
913    /** Escapes the components of a path String, returning an escaped full path String.
914     * Each path component is escaped with {@link #escapePathComponent(String)} and then joined using '/' characters.
915     * 
916     * <p>Opposite of {@link #splitEscapedPath(String)}.
917     * 
918     * @param pathComponents the filename components
919     * @return an escaped path
920     */
921    public static String createEscapedPath(String[] pathComponents) {
922        String result = null;
923        if (pathComponents.length == 0) { 
924                throw new IllegalArgumentException("empty pathComponents"); 
925        }
926        for (String c : pathComponents) {
927                if (c==null) { 
928                        throw new NullPointerException("null pathComponent"); 
929                }
930                if (result == null) {
931                        result = escapePathComponent(c);
932                } else {
933                        result = result + "/" + escapePathComponent(c); 
934                }
935        }
936        return result;
937    }
938    
939    // escapeCss from ESAPI 2.0.1
940    private static final String[] esapi_hex = new String[256];
941        static {
942                for ( char c = 0; c < 0xFF; c++ ) {
943                        if ( c >= 0x30 && c <= 0x39 || c >= 0x41 && c <= 0x5A || c >= 0x61 && c <= 0x7A ) {
944                                esapi_hex[c] = null;
945                        } else {
946                                esapi_hex[c] = toHex(c).intern();
947                        }
948                }
949        }
950        private static String toHex(char c) {
951                return Integer.toHexString(c);
952        }
953        private static String getHexForNonAlphanumeric(char c) {
954                if(c<0xFF) {return esapi_hex[c]; }
955                return toHex(c);
956        }
957    private static String encodeCssCharacter(Character c) {
958                String hex = getHexForNonAlphanumeric(c);
959                if ( hex == null ) { return "" + c; }
960        return "\\" + hex + " ";
961    }

963    /**
964     * Returns the CSS-escaped form of a string. 
965     * 
966     * <p>Characters outside of the printable ASCII range are converted to \nnnn form
967     *
968     * @param input the string to convert
969     *
970     * @return the HTML-escaped form of the string
971     */
972    public static String escapeCss(String input) {
973        if (input == null) { return ""; }
974        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
975                for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
976                        char c = input.charAt(i);
977                        sb.append(encodeCssCharacter(c));
978                }
979                return sb.toString();           
980    }

985    /** Returns the given string; but will truncate it to MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS.
986     *  If it exceeds this length, a message is appended expressing how many
987     *  characters were truncated. Strings with the key of 'exception' are
988     *  not truncated (in order to display full stack traces when these occur).
989     *  Any keys that contain the text 'password', 'Password', 'credential' or
990     *  'Credential' will be returned as eight asterisks.
991     *
992     * <p>This method is used in the debug JSP when dumping properties to the user,
993     *  in order to prevent inordinately verbose output.
994     *
995     *  @param key The key of the string we wish to display
996     *  @param string The string value
997     *  @return A (possibly truncated) version of this string
998     */
999    public static String getDisplayString(String key, String string) {
1000        return getDisplayString(key, string, MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS);
1001    }
1002
1003    /** Returns the given string; but will truncate it to MAX_STRING_OUTPUT_CHARS.
1004     *  If it exceeds this length, a message is appended expressing how many
1005     *  characters were truncated. Strings with the key of 'exception' are
1006     *  not truncated (in order to display full stack traces when these occur).
1007     *  Any keys that contain the text 'password', 'Password', 'credential' or
1008     *  'Credential' will be returned as eight asterisks.
1009     *
1010     * <p>This method is used in the debug JSP when dumping properties to the user,
1011     *  in order to prevent inordinately verbose output.
1012     *
1013     *  @param key The key of the string we wish to display
1014     *  @param string The string value
1015     *  @param maxChars The maximum number of characters to display
1016     *  
1017     *  @return A (possibly truncated) version of this string
1018     */
1019    public static String getDisplayString(String key, String string, int maxChars) {
1020        if (string == null) {
1021            string = "(null)";
1022        }
1023
1024        if ("exception".equals(key)) {
1025            return string;
1026        }
1027
1028        if (key.indexOf("password") >= 0 || key.indexOf("Password") >= 0 || key.indexOf("credential") >= 0 || key.indexOf("Credential") >= 0) {
1029            return "********";
1030        }
1031
1032        if (string.length() <= maxChars) {
1033            return string;
1034        } else {
1035            return string.substring(0, maxChars) + "... (" + (string.length() - maxChars) + " more characters truncated)";
1036        }
1037    }
1038
1039    /** Utility function to return a default if the supplied string is null.
1040     *  Shorthand for <code>(strText==null) ? strDefaultText : strText;</code>
1041     *
1042     * @return strText is strText is not null, otherwise strDefaultText
1043     */
1044    public static String strDefault(String strText, String strDefaultText) {
1045        return (strText == null) ? strDefaultText : strText;
1046    }

1048    /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter
1049     *
1050     * @param elements The array of elements to join
1051     * @return delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1052     *
1053     * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1054     */
1055    public static String join(String[] elements, String delimiter) {
1056        return joinWithLast(elements, false, delimiter, delimiter);
1057    }
1058
1059    /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter
1060     *
1061     * @param elements A Collection or Iterable of the elements to join
1062     * @return delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1063     *
1064     * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1065     */
1066    public static String join(Iterable elements, String delimiter) {
1067        return joinWithLast(elements, false, delimiter, delimiter);
1068    }
1069    
1070    /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter.
1071    * Each element is contained in single quotes. The final delimeter can be set to a different
1072    * value, to produce text in the form <code>"'a', 'b' or 'c'"</code> or <code>"'a', 'b' and 'c'"</code>. 
1073    *
1074    * <p>There is no special handling of values containing quotes; see {@link #escapeCsv(String)} 
1075    *
1076    * @param elements The array of elements to join
1077    * @param isQuoted If true, each element is surrounded by single quotes
1078    * @param delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1079    * @param lastDelimiter The delimiter to join the second-last and last elements
1080    *
1081    * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1082    */
1083   public static String joinWithLast(String[] elements, boolean isQuoted, String delimiter, String lastDelimiter) {
1084           StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
1085       if (elements == null) {
1086           throw new NullPointerException("null elements");
1087       }
1088       if (delimiter == null) {
1089           throw new NullPointerException("null delimiter");
1090       }
1091       if (lastDelimiter == null) {
1092           throw new NullPointerException("null lastDelimiter");
1093       }
1094       int len = elements.length;
1095       if (len == 0) {
1096           return "";
1097       }
1098
1099       for (int i = 0; i < len - 1; i++) {
1100           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1101           sb.append(elements[i]);
1102           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1103           if (i == len - 2) { sb.append(lastDelimiter); } else { sb.append(delimiter); }
1104       }
1105       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1106       sb.append(elements[len - 1]);
1107       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1108       return sb.toString();
1109   }
1110
1111   /** Return a string composed of a series of strings, separated with the specified delimiter
1112    *
1113    * <p>There is no special handling of values containing quotes; see {@link #escapeCsv(String)} 
1114    *
1115    * @param elements A Collection or Iterable containing the elements to join
1116    * @param isQuoted If true, each element is surrounded by single quotes
1117    * @param delimiter The delimiter to join each string with
1118    * @param lastDelimiter The delimiter to join the second-last and last elements
1119    *
1120    * @throws NullPointerException if elements or delimiter is null
1121    *
1122    * @see #join(String[], String)
1123    */
1124   public static String joinWithLast(Iterable<?> elements, boolean isQuoted, String delimiter, String lastDelimiter) {
1125        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
1126       if (elements == null) {
1127           throw new NullPointerException("null elements");
1128       }
1129       if (delimiter == null) {
1130           throw new NullPointerException("null delimiter");
1131       }
1132       if (lastDelimiter == null) {
1133           throw new NullPointerException("null lastDelimiter");
1134       }
1135       Iterator<?> i = elements.iterator();
1136       if (!i.hasNext()) { return ""; } 
1137       
1138       Object thisEl = i.next();
1139       while (i.hasNext()) {
1140           Object nextEl = i.next();
1141           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1142           sb.append(thisEl);
1143           if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1144           if (i.hasNext()) {
1145               sb.append(delimiter);
1146           } else {
1147                   sb.append(lastDelimiter);
1148           }
1149           thisEl = nextEl;
1150       }
1151       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1152       sb.append(thisEl);
1153       if (isQuoted) { sb.append("'"); }
1154       
1155       return sb.toString();
1156   }
1157    
1158    
1159    
1160
1161    /*
1162     * efficient search & replace ... stolen from Usenet:
1163     * http://groups.google.co.uk/groups?hl=en&lr=&selm=memo.19990629182431.344B%40none.crap
1164     */
1165
1166    /**
1167     * An efficient search &amp; replace routine. Replaces all instances of
1168     * searchString within str with replaceString.
1169     *
1170     * @param originalString The string to search
1171     * @param searchString The string to search for
1172     * @param replaceString The string to replace it with
1173     *
1174     */
1175    public static String replaceString(String originalString, String searchString, String replaceString) {
1176        if (replaceString == null) {
1177            return originalString;
1178        }
1179
1180        if (searchString == null) {
1181            return originalString;
1182        }
1183
1184        if (originalString == null) {
1185            return null;
1186        }
1187
1188        int loc = originalString.indexOf(searchString);
1189
1190        if (loc == -1) {
1191            return originalString;
1192        }
1193
1194        char[] src = originalString.toCharArray();
1195        int n = searchString.length();
1196        int m = originalString.length();
1197        StringBuilder buf = new StringBuilder(m + replaceString.length() - n);
1198        int start = 0;
1199
1200        do {
1201            if (loc > start) {
1202                buf.append(src, start, loc - start);
1203            }
1204
1205            buf.append(replaceString);
1206            start = loc + n;
1207            loc = originalString.indexOf(searchString, start);
1208        } while (loc > 0);
1209
1210        if (start < m) {
1211            buf.append(src, start, m - start);
1212        }
1213
1214        return buf.toString();
1215    }
1216
1217    /**
1218     * Reads a file, and returns its contents in a String
1219     *
1220     * @param filename The file to read
1221     *
1222     * @return The contents of the string,
1223     *
1224     * @throws IOException A problem occurred whilst attempting to read the string
1225     */
1226    public static String getFileContents(String filename)
1227        throws IOException {
1228        File file = new File(filename);
1229        FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file);
1230        byte[] data = new byte[(int) file.length()];
1231        int len = fis.read(data);
1232        fis.close();
1233        if (len < file.length()) {
1234            /* this should never happen -- file has changed underneath us */
1235            throw new IOException("Buffer read != size of file");
1236        }
1237
1238        return new String(data);
1239    }
1240
1241    /**
1242     * Reads a file, and returns its contents in a String. Identical to calling
1243     * <code>getFileContents(projectFile.getCanonicalPath())</code>.
1244     *
1245     * @param file The file to read
1246     *
1247     * @return The contents of the string,
1248     * @throws IOException 
1249     *
1250     * @throws IOException A problem occurred whilst attempting to read the string
1251     */
1252        public static String getFileContents(File file) throws IOException {
1253                return getFileContents(file.getCanonicalPath());
1254        }

1256    
1257    /**
1258     * Prefixes every lines supplied with a given indent. e.g.
1259     * <code>indent("\t", "abcd\nefgh")</code> would return "\tabcd\n\tefgh". If the
1260     * string ends in a newline, then the return value also ends with a newline.
1261     *
1262     * @param indentString   The characters to indent with. Usually spaces or tabs,
1263     *   but could be something like a timestamp.
1264     * @param originalString The string to indent.
1265     * @return The originalString, with every line (as separated by the newline
1266     *   character) prefixed with indentString.
1267     */
1268    static public String indent(String indentString, String originalString) {
1269        String allButLastChar;
1270        if (originalString == null || indentString == null) {
1271            throw new NullPointerException();
1272        }
1273        if (originalString.equals("")) {
1274            return indentString;
1275        }
1276        allButLastChar = originalString.substring(0, originalString.length() - 1);
1277        return indentString + replaceString(allButLastChar, "\n", "\n" + indentString) + originalString.substring(originalString.length() - 1);
1278    }
1279    
1280    /** Ensure that a string is padded with spaces so that it meets the 
1281     * required length. If the input string exceeds this length, this it 
1282     * is returned unchanged
1283     * 
1284     * @param inputString the string to pad
1285     * @param length the desired length
1286     * @param justification a JUSTIFICATION_* constant defining whether left or 
1287     *   right justification is required.
1288     * 
1289     * @return a padded string. 
1290     */
1291    static public String pad(String inputString, int length, int justification) {
1292        // @TODO not terribly efficient, but who cares
1293        switch (justification) {
1294                case JUSTIFICATION_LEFT:
1295                        while (inputString.length() < length) { 
1296                                inputString = inputString + " ";
1297                        }
1298                        break;
1299
1300                        case JUSTIFICATION_RIGHT:
1301                                while (inputString.length() < length) { 
1302                                        inputString = " " + inputString;
1303                                }
1304                                break;
1305                        
1306                        case JUSTIFICATION_CENTER:
1307                                while (inputString.length() < length) { 
1308                                        inputString = inputString + " ";
1309                                        if (inputString.length() < length) {
1310                                                inputString = " " + inputString;
1311                                        }
1312                                }
1313                                break;
1314        }
1315        return inputString;
1316    }
1317
1318    /** Given a period-separated list of components (e.g. variable references ("a.b.c") or classnames),
1319     *  returns the last component. For example,
1320     *  getLastComponent("com.randomnoun.common.util.Text") will return "Text".
1321     *
1322     *  <p>If component is null, this function returns null.
1323     *  <p>If component contains no periods, this function returns the original string.
1324     *
1325     *  @param string The string to retrieve the last component from
1326     */
1327    static public String getLastComponent(String string) {
1328        if (string == null) {
1329            return null;
1330        }
1331        if (string.indexOf('.') == -1) {
1332            return string;
1333        }
1334        return string.substring(string.lastIndexOf('.') + 1);
1335    }
1336
1337    /** Escape this supplied string so it can represent a 'name' or 'value' component
1338     * on a HTTP queryString. This generally involves escaping special characters into %xx
1339     * form. Note that this only works for US-ASCII data.
1340     *
1341     */
1342    public static String escapeQueryString(String unescapedQueryString) {
1343        // default encoding
1344        byte[] data = encodeUrl(allowed_within_query, unescapedQueryString.getBytes());
1345
1346        try {
1347            return new String(data, "US-ASCII");
1348        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {
1349            throw new RuntimeException("encodeQueryString() requires ASCII support");
1350        }
1351    }
1352
1353    /**
1354     * Encodes an array of bytes into an array of URL safe 7-bit
1355     * characters. Unsafe characters are escaped.
1356     *
1357     * @param urlsafe bitset of characters deemed URL safe
1358     * @param bytes array of bytes to convert to URL safe characters
1359     * @return array of bytes containing URL safe characters
1360     */
1361    private static final byte[] encodeUrl(BitSet urlsafe, byte[] bytes) {
1362        if (bytes == null) {
1363            return null;
1364        }
1365
1366        if (urlsafe == null) {
1367            throw new NullPointerException("null urlsafe");
1368        }
1369
1370        ByteArrayOutputStream buffer = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
1371
1372        for (int i = 0; i < bytes.length; i++) {
1373            int b = bytes[i];
1374
1375            if (b < 0) {
1376                b = 256 + b;
1377            }
1378
1379            if (urlsafe.get(b)) {
1380                if (b == ' ') {
1381                    b = '+';
1382                }
1383
1384                buffer.write(b);
1385            } else {
1386                buffer.write('%');
1387
1388                char hex1 = Character.toUpperCase(Character.forDigit((b >> 4) & 0xF, 16));
1389                char hex2 = Character.toUpperCase(Character.forDigit(b & 0xF, 16));
1390
1391                buffer.write(hex1);
1392                buffer.write(hex2);
1393            }
1394        }
1395
1396        return buffer.toByteArray();
1397    }
1398
1399    /**
1400     * Encodes a string into Base64 format.
1401     * No blanks or line breaks are inserted.
1402     * @param s  a String to be encoded.
1403     * @return   A String with the Base64 encoded data.
1404     */
1405    public static String encodeBase64(String s) {
1406        return new String(encodeBase64(s.getBytes()));
1407    }
1408
1409    /**
1410     * Encodes a byte array into Base64 format.
1411     * No blanks or line breaks are inserted.
1412     * @param in  an array containing the data bytes to be encoded.
1413     * @return    A character array with the Base64 encoded data.
1414     */
1415    public static char[] encodeBase64(byte[] in) {
1416        int iLen = in.length;
1417        int oDataLen = (iLen * 4 + 2) / 3; // output length without padding
1418        int oLen = ((iLen + 2) / 3) * 4; // output length including padding
1419        char[] out = new char[oLen];
1420        int ip = 0;
1421        int op = 0;
1422
1423        while (ip < iLen) {
1424            int i0 = in[ip++] & 0xff;
1425            int i1 = ip < iLen ? in[ip++] & 0xff : 0;
1426            int i2 = ip < iLen ? in[ip++] & 0xff : 0;
1427            int o0 = i0 >>> 2;
1428            int o1 = ((i0 & 3) << 4) | (i1 >>> 4);
1429            int o2 = ((i1 & 0xf) << 2) | (i2 >>> 6);
1430            int o3 = i2 & 0x3F;
1431            out[op++] = map1[o0];
1432            out[op++] = map1[o1];
1433            out[op] = op < oDataLen ? map1[o2] : '=';
1434            op++;
1435            out[op] = op < oDataLen ? map1[o3] : '=';
1436            op++;
1437        }
1438        return out;
1439    }
1440
1441        /** Used by {@link #parseData(String) to parse dates generated in Codec output.
1442         * (These dates are generated using the standard Java .toString() method, which
1443         * probably changes depending on the VM's locale, which I'm going to ignore for 
1444         * the time being).
1445         */
1446        static class DateParser {
1447                
1448                /** Parse a date generated by Date.toString() into a Date object
1449                 * 
1450                 * @param dateString a string representation of a date
1451                 * @return a Date representation of a date
1452                 */
1453                public static Date valueOf(String dateString) {
1454                        SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("EEE MMM dd hh:mm:ss z yyyy");
1455                        try {
1456                                return sdf.parse(dateString);
1457                        } catch (ParseException pe) {
1458                                throw (IllegalArgumentException) new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid date '" + dateString + "'").initCause(pe);
1459                        }
1460                }
1461        }
1462
1463    // ---------------------- Generous characters for each component validation
1464    // -- not much of this is used in this class, so I should shorten these definitions, 
1465    // but you never know, I might use it later, so it's here for the time being.
1466    // 
1467    // compiled from
1468    //  org.apache.commons.httpclient.util.URIUtil
1469    //  org.apache.commons.codec.net.URLCodec
1470    //  org.apache.commons.httpclient.util.EncodingUtil
1471    //  org.apache.commons.httpclient.URI
1472    //
1473    // trust me... just calling escapeQueryString() is *so* much easier.
1474    private static final BitSet percent = new BitSet(256); // escape % as %25
1475    private static final BitSet digit = new BitSet(256); // 0-9
1476    private static final BitSet alpha = new BitSet(256); // lowalpha | upalpha
1477    private static final BitSet alphanum = new BitSet(256); // alpha | digit
1478    private static final BitSet hex = new BitSet(256); // digit | a-f | A-F
1479    private static final BitSet escaped = new BitSet(256); // "%" hex hex
1480    private static final BitSet mark = new BitSet(256); // -_.!~*'()
1481    private static final BitSet unreserved = new BitSet(256);
1482
1483    // alphanum | mark (URI allowed, no purpose)
1484    private static final BitSet reserved = new BitSet(256); // ;/?:"&=+$,
1485    private static final BitSet uric = new BitSet(256);
1486
1487    // reserved | unreserved | escaped
1488    private static final BitSet allowed_query = new BitSet(256); // uric - %
1489    private static final BitSet allowed_within_query = new BitSet(256);
1490
1491    /** Mapping table from 6-bit nibble to Base64 characters */
1492    private static char[] map1 = new char[64];
1493
1494    // NB: www-form-encoding appears to be alpha | numeric | -_.* ( + space) 
1495    static {
1496        percent.set('%');
1497
1498        for (int i = '0'; i <= '9'; i++) {
1499            digit.set(i);
1500        }
1501
1502        for (int i = 'a'; i <= 'z'; i++) {
1503            alpha.set(i);
1504        }
1505
1506        for (int i = 'A'; i <= 'Z'; i++) {
1507            alpha.set(i);
1508        }
1509
1510        alphanum.or(alpha);
1511        alphanum.or(digit);
1512        hex.or(digit);
1513
1514        for (int i = 'a'; i <= 'f'; i++) {
1515            hex.set(i);
1516        }
1517
1518        for (int i = 'A'; i <= 'F'; i++) {
1519            hex.set(i);
1520        }
1521
1522        escaped.or(percent);
1523        escaped.or(hex);
1524        mark.set('-');
1525        mark.set('_');
1526        mark.set('.');
1527        mark.set('!');
1528        mark.set('~');
1529        mark.set('*');
1530        mark.set('\'');
1531        mark.set('(');
1532        mark.set(')');
1533        reserved.set(';');
1534        reserved.set('/');
1535        reserved.set('?');
1536        reserved.set(':');
1537        reserved.set('@');
1538        reserved.set('&');
1539        reserved.set('=');
1540        reserved.set('+');
1541        reserved.set('$');
1542        reserved.set(',');
1543        unreserved.or(alphanum);
1544        unreserved.or(mark);
1545        uric.or(reserved);
1546        uric.or(unreserved);
1547        uric.or(escaped);
1548        allowed_query.or(uric);
1549        allowed_query.clear('%');
1550        allowed_within_query.or(allowed_query);
1551        allowed_within_query.andNot(reserved);
1552
1553
1554        // excluded 'reserved'                       
1555        // create map1 array
1556        int i = 0;
1557        for (char c = 'A'; c <= 'Z'; c++) {
1558            map1[i++] = c;
1559        }
1560        for (char c = 'a'; c <= 'z'; c++) {
1561            map1[i++] = c;
1562        }
1563        for (char c = '0'; c <= '9'; c++) {
1564            map1[i++] = c;
1565        }
1566        map1[i++] = '+';
1567        map1[i++] = '/';
1568        
1569    }
