1572
1573    /**
1574     * Returns a comparator that compares contained numbers based on their numeric values and compares other parts
1575     * using the current locale's order rules.
1576     * <p>For example in German locale this will be a comparator that handles umlauts correctly and ignores
1577     * upper/lower case differences.</p>
1578     *
1579     * @return <p>A string comparator that uses the current locale's order rules and handles embedded numbers
1580     *         correctly.</p>
1581     */
1582    public static Comparator getNaturalComparator() {
1583        final Collator collator = Collator.getInstance();
1584        return new Comparator() {
1585            public int compare(Object o1, Object o2) {
1586                return compareNatural(collator, (String) o1, (String) o2);
1587            }
1588        };
1589    }    
1590
1591    /**
1592     * <p>Compares two strings using the current locale's rules and comparing contained numbers based on their numeric
1593     * values.</p>
1594     * <p>This is probably the best default comparison to use.</p>
1595     * <p>If you know that the texts to be compared are in a certain language that differs from the default locale's
1596     * langage, then get a collator for the desired locale ({@link java.text.Collator#getInstance(java.util.Locale)})
1597     * and pass it to {@link #compareNatural(java.text.Collator, String, String)}</p>
1598     *
1599     * @param s first string
1600     * @param t second string
1601     * @return zero iff <code>s</code> and <code>t</code> are equal,
1602     *         a value less than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically precedes <code>t</code>
1603     *         and a value larger than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically follows <code>t</code>
1604     */
1605    public static int compareNatural(Collator collator, String s, String t) {
1606        return compareNatural(s, t, false, collator);
1607    }
1608
1609
1610    /** Natural compare operation. Stolen from 
1611     * http://www.eekboom.com/java/compareNatural/src/com/eekboom/utils/Strings.java
1612     * (source file is under BSD license). 
1613     * 
1614     * @param s             first string
1615     * @param t             second string
1616     * @param caseSensitive treat characters differing in case only as equal - will be ignored if a collator is given
1617     * @param collator      used to compare subwords that aren't numbers - if null, characters will be compared
1618     *                      individually based on their Unicode value
1619     * @return zero iff <code>s</code> and <code>t</code> are equal,
1620     *         a value less than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically precedes <code>t</code>
1621     *         and a value larger than zero iff <code>s</code> lexicographically follows <code>t</code>
1622     */
1623    private static int compareNatural(String s, String t, boolean caseSensitive, Collator collator) {
1624        int sIndex = 0;
1625        int tIndex = 0;
1626
1627        int sLength = s.length();
1628        int tLength = t.length();
1629
1630        while(true) {
1631            // both character indices are after a subword (or at zero)
1632
1633            // Check if one string is at end
1634            if(sIndex == sLength && tIndex == tLength) {
1635                return 0;
1636            }
1637            if(sIndex == sLength) {
1638                return -1;
1639            }
1640            if(tIndex == tLength) {
1641                return 1;
1642            }
1643
1644            // Compare sub word
1645            char sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1646            char tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1647
1648            boolean sCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(sChar);
1649            boolean tCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(tChar);
1650
1651            if(sCharIsDigit && tCharIsDigit) {
1652                // Compare numbers
1653
1654                // skip leading 0s
1655                int sLeadingZeroCount = 0;
1656                while(sChar == '0') {
1657                    ++sLeadingZeroCount;
1658                    ++sIndex;
1659                    if(sIndex == sLength) {
1660                        break;
1661                    }
1662                    sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1663                }
1664                int tLeadingZeroCount = 0;
1665                while(tChar == '0') {
1666                    ++tLeadingZeroCount;
1667                    ++tIndex;
1668                    if(tIndex == tLength) {
1669                        break;
1670                    }
1671                    tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1672                }
1673                boolean sAllZero = sIndex == sLength || !Character.isDigit(sChar);
1674                boolean tAllZero = tIndex == tLength || !Character.isDigit(tChar);
1675                if(sAllZero && tAllZero) {
1676                    continue;
1677                }
1678                if(sAllZero && !tAllZero) {
1679                    return -1;
1680                }
1681                if(tAllZero) {
1682                    return 1;
1683                }
1684
1685                int diff = 0;
1686                do {
1687                    if(diff == 0) {
1688                        diff = sChar - tChar;
1689                    }
1690                    ++sIndex;
1691                    ++tIndex;
1692                    if(sIndex == sLength && tIndex == tLength) {
1693                        return diff != 0 ? diff : sLeadingZeroCount - tLeadingZeroCount;
1694                    }
1695                    if(sIndex == sLength) {
1696                        if(diff == 0) {
1697                            return -1;
1698                        }
1699                        return Character.isDigit(t.charAt(tIndex)) ? -1 : diff;
1700                    }
1701                    if(tIndex == tLength) {
1702                        if(diff == 0) {
1703                            return 1;
1704                        }
1705                        return Character.isDigit(s.charAt(sIndex)) ? 1 : diff;
1706                    }
1707                    sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1708                    tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1709                    sCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(sChar);
1710                    tCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(tChar);
1711                    if(!sCharIsDigit && !tCharIsDigit) {
1712                        // both number sub words have the same length
1713                        if(diff != 0) {
1714                            return diff;
1715                        }
1716                        break;
1717                    }
1718                    if(!sCharIsDigit) {
1719                        return -1;
1720                    }
1721                    if(!tCharIsDigit) {
1722                        return 1;
1723                    }
1724                } while(true);
1725            }
1726            else {
1727                // Compare words
1728                if(collator != null) {
1729                    // To use the collator the whole subwords have to be compared - character-by-character comparision
1730                    // is not possible. So find the two subwords first
1731                    int aw = sIndex;
1732                    int bw = tIndex;
1733                    do {
1734                        ++sIndex;
1735                    } while(sIndex < sLength && !Character.isDigit(s.charAt(sIndex)));
1736                    do {
1737                        ++tIndex;
1738                    } while(tIndex < tLength && !Character.isDigit(t.charAt(tIndex)));
1739
1740                    String as = s.substring(aw, sIndex);
1741                    String bs = t.substring(bw, tIndex);
1742                    int subwordResult = collator.compare(as, bs);
1743                    if(subwordResult != 0) {
1744                        return subwordResult;
1745                    }
1746                }
1747                else {
1748                    // No collator specified. All characters should be ascii only. Compare character-by-character.
1749                    do {
1750                        if(sChar != tChar) {
1751                            if(caseSensitive) {
1752                                return sChar - tChar;
1753                            }
1754                            sChar = Character.toUpperCase(sChar);
1755                            tChar = Character.toUpperCase(tChar);
1756                            if(sChar != tChar) {
1757                                sChar = Character.toLowerCase(sChar);
1758                                tChar = Character.toLowerCase(tChar);
1759                                if(sChar != tChar) {
1760                                    return sChar - tChar;
1761                                }
1762                            }
1763                        }
1764                        ++sIndex;
1765                        ++tIndex;
1766                        if(sIndex == sLength && tIndex == tLength) {
1767                            return 0;
1768                        }
1769                        if(sIndex == sLength) {
1770                            return -1;
1771                        }
1772                        if(tIndex == tLength) {
1773                            return 1;
1774                        }
1775                        sChar = s.charAt(sIndex);
1776                        tChar = t.charAt(tIndex);
1777                        sCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(sChar);
1778                        tCharIsDigit = Character.isDigit(tChar);
1779                    } while(!sCharIsDigit && !tCharIsDigit);
1780                }
1781            }
1782        }
1783    }
1784
1785
1786        // taken from the W3C Jigsaw server sourcecode; class org.w3c.jigsaw.http.Request#unescape(String)
1787        /**
1788         * Unescape a HTTP escaped string
1789         * @param s The string to be unescaped
1790         * @return the unescaped string.
1791         */
1792        public static String unescapeQueryString (String s) {
1793                StringBuilder sbuf = new StringBuilder() ;
1794                int len  = s.length() ;
1795                int ch = -1 ;
1796                for (int i = 0 ; i < len ; i++) {
1797                        switch (ch = s.charAt(i)) {
1798                                case '%':
1799                                        if (i < len - 2) {
1800                                                // @TODO check to see how illegal escapes are treated
1801                                                // e.g. "%nothex"
1802                                                ch = s.charAt (++i) ;
1803                                                int hb = (Character.isDigit ((char) ch) 
1804                                                          ? ch - '0'
1805                                                          : 10+Character.toLowerCase ((char) ch)-'a') & 0xF ;
1806                                                ch = s.charAt (++i) ;
1807                                                int lb = (Character.isDigit ((char) ch)
1808                                                          ? ch - '0'
1809                                                          : 10+Character.toLowerCase ((char) ch)-'a') & 0xF ;
1810                                                sbuf.append ((char) ((hb << 4) | lb)) ;
1811                                        } else {
1812                                                sbuf.append ('%');  // hit EOL, just leave as is
1813                                        }
1814                                        break ;
1815                                case '+':
1816                                        sbuf.append (' ') ;
1817                                        break ;
1818                                default:
1819                                        sbuf.append ((char) ch) ;
1820                        }
1821                }
1822                return sbuf.toString() ;
1823        }
1824        
1825        /** Returns the largest common prefix between two other strings; e.g. 
1826         * getCommonPrefix("abcsomething", "abcsometharg") would be "abcsometh".
1827         * 
1828         * @param string1 String number one
1829         * @param string2 String number two
1830         * 
1831         * @return the large common prefix between the two strings
1832         * 
1833         * @throws NullPointerException is string1 or string2 is null
1834         */
1835        public static String getCommonPrefix(String string1, String string2) {
1836                if (string1==null) { throw new NullPointerException("null string1"); }
1837                if (string2==null) { throw new NullPointerException("null string2"); }
1838                int c = 0;
1839                int maxLen = Math.min(string1.length(), string2.length());              
1840                
1841                while (c < maxLen && string1.charAt(c)==string2.charAt(c)) {
1842                        c++;
1843                }
1844                return string1.substring(0, c);
1845        }
1846
1847        /** Uppercases the first character of a string.
1848     * 
1849     * @param text text to modify
1850     * 
1851     * @return the supplied text, with the first character converted to uppercase.
1852     */
1853    static public String toFirstUpper(String text) {
1854        return Character.toUpperCase(text.charAt(0)) + text.substring(1); 
1855    }
1856
1857
1858        /** Lowercases the first character of a string.
1859     * 
1860     * @param text text to modify
1861     * 
1862     * @return the supplied text, with the first character converted to lowercase.
1863     */
1864    static public String toFirstLower(String text) {
1865        return Character.toLowerCase(text.charAt(0)) + text.substring(1); 
1866    }

1869
1870    
1871    /** Number of character edits between two strings; taken from  
1872         * http://www.merriampark.com/ldjava.htm. There's a version in commongs-lang,
1873         * apparently, but according to the comments on that page, it uses O(n^2) memory,
1874         * which can't be good.
1875         * 
1876         * @param s string 1
1877         * @param t string 2
1878         *  
1879         * @return the smallest number of edits required to convert s into t 
1880         */
1881        public static int getLevenshteinDistance (String s, String t) {
1882                  if (s == null || t == null) {
1883                    throw new IllegalArgumentException("Strings must not be null");
1884                  }
1885                                
1886                  /*
1887                    The difference between this impl. and the previous is that, rather 
1888                     than creating and retaining a matrix of size s.length()+1 by t.length()+1, 
1889                     we maintain two single-dimensional arrays of length s.length()+1.  The first, d,
1890                     is the 'current working' distance array that maintains the newest distance cost
1891                     counts as we iterate through the characters of String s.  Each time we increment
1892                     the index of String t we are comparing, d is copied to p, the second int[].  Doing so
1893                     allows us to retain the previous cost counts as required by the algorithm (taking 
1894                     the minimum of the cost count to the left, up one, and diagonally up and to the left
1895                     of the current cost count being calculated).  (Note that the arrays aren't really 
1896                     copied anymore, just switched...this is clearly much better than cloning an array 
1897                     or doing a System.arraycopy() each time  through the outer loop.)
1898
1899                     Effectively, the difference between the two implementations is this one does not 
1900                     cause an out of memory condition when calculating the LD over two very large strings.              
1901                  */            
1902                                
1903                  int n = s.length(); // length of s
1904                  int m = t.length(); // length of t
1905                                
1906                  if (n == 0) {
1907                    return m;
1908                  } else if (m == 0) {
1909                    return n;
1910                  }
1911
1912                  int p[] = new int[n+1]; //'previous' cost array, horizontally
1913                  int d[] = new int[n+1]; // cost array, horizontally
1914                  int _d[]; //placeholder to assist in swapping p and d
1915
1916                  // indexes into strings s and t
1917                  int i; // iterates through s
1918                  int j; // iterates through t
1919
1920                  char t_j; // jth character of t
1921
1922                  int cost; // cost
1923
1924                  for (i = 0; i<=n; i++) {
1925                     p[i] = i;
1926                  }
1927                                
1928                  for (j = 1; j<=m; j++) {
1929                     t_j = t.charAt(j-1);
1930                     d[0] = j;
1931                                
1932                     for (i=1; i<=n; i++) {
1933                        cost = s.charAt(i-1)==t_j ? 0 : 1;
1934                        // minimum of cell to the left+1, to the top+1, diagonally left and up +cost                            
1935                        d[i] = Math.min(Math.min(d[i-1]+1, p[i]+1),  p[i-1]+cost);  
1936                     }
1937
1938                     // copy current distance counts to 'previous row' distance counts
1939                     _d = p;
1940                     p = d;
1941                     d = _d;
1942                  } 
1943                                
1944                  // our last action in the above loop was to switch d and p, so p now 
1945                  // actually has the most recent cost counts
1946                  return p[n];
1947        }
1948    
1949        /** Return the md5 hash of a string
1950     * 
1951     * @param text text to hash
1952     * 
1953     * @return a hex-encoded version of the MD5 hash
1954     * 
1955     * @throws IllegalStateException if the java installation in use doesn't know 
1956     *   about MD5
1957     */
1958    static public String getMD5(String text) {
1959        try{
1960                MessageDigest algorithm = MessageDigest.getInstance("MD5");
1961                algorithm.reset();
1962                // algorithm.update(defaultBytes);
1963                algorithm.update(text.getBytes());
1964                byte messageDigest[] = algorithm.digest();
1965                    
1966                StringBuilder hexString = new StringBuilder();
1967                for (int i=0;i<messageDigest.length;i++) {
1968                        hexString.append(Integer.toHexString(0xFF & messageDigest[i]));
1969                }
1970                return hexString.toString();
1971        } catch (NoSuchAlgorithmException nsae) {
1972                throw (IllegalStateException) new IllegalStateException("Unknown algorithm 'MD5'").initCause(nsae);
1973        }
1974    }
1975    
1976    /** Returns a string composed of the supplied text, repeated 0 or more times 
1977     * 
1978     * @param text text to repeat
1979     * @param count number of repetitions
1980     * 
1981     * @return the repeated text
1982     */
1983    static public String repeat(String text, int count) {
1984        StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
1985        for (int i=0; i<count; i++) {
1986                sb.append(text);
1987        }
1988        return sb.toString();
1989    }
1990    
1991    
1992        /** Perform ${xxxx}-style substitution of placeholders in text. Placeholders without 
1993         * values will be left as-is.
1994         * 
1995         * <p>For example, gives the set of variables:
1996         * <ul>
1997         * <li>abc = def
1998         * </ul>
1999         * 
2000         * <p>then the result of <code>substituteParameters("xxxx${abc}yyyy${def}zzzz")</code>
2001         * will be "xxxxdefyyyy${def}zzzz"
2002         * 
2003         * <p><code>$</code> followed by any other character will be left as-is. 
2004         * 
2005         * @param variables a set of variable names and values, used in the substitution 
2006         * @param text the text to be substituted.
2007         * 
2008         * @return text, with placeholders replaced with values in the variables parameter
2009         */
2010        public static String substitutePlaceholders(Map variables, String text) {
2011                // escaped version of (\$\{.*?\}|[^$]+|\$.)
2012                Pattern p = Pattern.compile("(\\$\\{.*?\\}|[^$]+|\\$)"); // modified regex
2013                Matcher m = p.matcher(text);
2014                String result = "";
2015                while (m.find()) {
2016                        String token = m.group(1);
2017                        if (token.startsWith("${") && token.endsWith("}")) {
2018                                Object value = variables.get(token.substring(2, token.length()-1));
2019                                if (value == null) {
2020                                        result = result + token;
2021                                } else {
2022                                        result = result + value.toString();
2023                                }
2024                        } else {
2025                                result = result + token;
2026                        }
2027                }
2028                return result;
2029        }
2030
2031        
2032}
